metadata.title: Projecting the second outbreaks for global COVID-19 pandemic

abstract.text: COVID-19 is now in an epidemic phase, with a second outbreak likely to appear 14 at any time. The intensity and timing of a second outbreak is a common concern 15 worldwide. In this study, we made scenario projections of the potential second outbreak 16 of COVID-19 using a statistical-epidemiology model, which considers both the impact 17 of seasonal changes in meteorological elements and human social behaviors such as 18 protests and city unblocking. Recent street protests in the United States and other 19 countries are identified as a hidden trigger and amplifier of the second outbreak. The 20 scale and intensity of subsequent COVID-19 outbreaks in the U.S. cities where the 21 epidemic is under initial control are projected to be much greater than those of the first 22

body_text.text: outbreak. For countries without reported protests, lifting the COVID-19 related 23 restrictions prematurely would accelerate the spread of the disease and place mounting 24 pressure on the local medical system that is already overloaded. We anticipate these 25 projections will support public health planning and policymaking by governments and 26 international organizations.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted July 16, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.07.15.20154161 doi: medRxiv preprint 1 Introduction 28 Recently, the COVID-19 pandemic has spread rapidly and poses a dire threat to global 29 public health, which claimed over 0.49 million lives, along with 9.8 million confirmed cases 30 as of June 28 th 1 . Beyond the spread itself, the outbreak may have far-reaching consequences, 31 negatively affecting the economic development worldwide and posing a series of long-standing 32 social problems 2,3 . There is an urgent need for a global prediction system that can provide 33 scientific guidelines for the World Health Organization and international decision-makers to 34 implement effective containment measures capable of curbing the spread of COVID-19 4 . 35 Researchers worldwide have developed various models with mathematical and statistical 36 methods, including stochastic simulations, lognormal distribution 5 , machine learning, and 37 artificial intelligence 6 . Among them, the susceptible-infectious-removed infectious disease 38 model (SIR) is the most widely used 7-9 . However, this simple model is built under a series of 39 idealized assumptions, which may limit the accuracy and reliability of the prediction. In order 40 to obtain the prediction results with higher credibility, more complex models with fewer 41 assumptions should be developed so as to simulate the actual situations in a more realistic 42 manner 10 . 43 Although it is difficult to establish an accurate epidemiological model describing the 44 spread of a pandemic, the reported global pandemic data contain particular solutions to the 45 mathematical equations incorporated in epidemiological models 3,6 . It is theoretically possible 46 to remedy the defects of prior epidemiological models by introducing the latest pandemic data 47 and hence improve the pandemic prediction 2,4,6 . Based on this idea, we have developed a 48 Global Prediction System of the COVID-19 Pandemic (GPCP) 11 . The system develops a 49 modified version of the SIR model and determines the parameters through historical data 50 fitting 12,13 , which allows it to make targeted predictions for various countries and obtain better 51 prediction results. The first version of GPCP (CPCP-1) can capture the major features of the 52 daily number of confirmed new cases and provides reliable predictions. However, the 53 prediction of GPCP-1 is only valid for one month 11 . 54 . If the timing collected from news reports is not explicit enough as an input to our 82 model, the timing will be indicated by the daily new cases on the day of reopening (dQc). As 83 the number of newly confirmed cases on a given day falls lower than dQc, local authority begins 84 to lift or loose the lockdowns. 85 In addition, the temporal variation of transmission rate due to changes in local temperature 86 as well as human behaviors are considered. Generally, the transmission rate ( ( ) ) can be 87 expressed by the following equations: 104 . FIGREF0.text: of meteorological elements and human social behaviors including protests 57 and city unblocking. The paper is arranged as follows: the details of the datasets and the 58 methodology used are given in section 2. In section 3, projections of 12 cities in the United 59 States are presented. The projections of 15 countries with reported protests and version of Global Prediction System for COVID-19 Pandemic (GPCP) is built 65 based on a modified SEIR model 15 . The traditional SEIR model 10,14 defines seven states of the 66 disease: susceptible cases (S), insusceptible cases (P), potentially infected cases (E, infected 67 cases in a latent period), infectious cases (I, infected cases that have not been quarantined), 68 quarantined cases (Q, confirmed and quarantined cases), recovered cases (R), and cases of 69 mortality (D). The SEIR model is able to emulate the time curve of an outbreak.

FIGREF1.text: represents the transmission rate in the non-intervention period at the early stage of 90 the pandemic ( < ); 1 represents the transmission rate during the intervention period 91 ( ≤ < ); 2 represents the transmission rate after the restriction is lifted. 0 and 1 92 are fitted against the actual reported data, while 2 is the assumed value in possible future 93 scenarios. We assume a 14-day delay in the effect of the intervention on the infection rate. ( ) 94 is the PDF function obtained by Huang et al. 16 , who found that 60.0% of confirmed COVID-95 19 cases occurred in places where the air temperature ranged from 5°C to 15°C. Using the 96 NCEP reanalysis data, we calculated the global distribution of probability distribution function 97 (PDF) values on each day of the year and included its influence on the infection rate. Figure 1 98 shows the PDF values for the four seasons in a year. High PDF values correspond to the ambient 99 temperature that is conducive for the virus to spread. For the northern hemisphere, the optimal 100 band generally moves northward in summer (June, July, and August) and moves southward in 101 winter (December, January, and February), while for southern hemisphere the optimal band 102 moves southward in summer (December, January, and February) and moves northward in 103 winter (June, July, and August).

FIGREF2.text: The optimal temperature zone for the spread COVID-19. Regions with warm 106 shadings indicate more conducive temperature for the spread of the virus and vice versa. 107 Since the seasonality of transmission is still disputed and future trajectory of the outbreaks 108 may be influenced by the intensity of intervention measures, four future scenarios are designed 109 to project the epidemic after easing COVID-19 related restrictions: Scenario 1: The restrictions are completely lifted after ( 2 = 0 ). The seasonal forcing 111 on the transmission rate is considered (E = 1). The restrictions are partially lifted after ( 2 = ( 0 + 1 )/2 ). The seasonal 113 forcing on the transmission rate is considered (E = 1). The restrictions are completely lifted after ( 2 = 0 ). The seasonal forcing 115 on the transmission rate is not considered (E = 0). The

FIGREF3.text: for all damping coefficient greater than 0, the coefficient matrix is positive definite 126 which makes the Hessian matrix in the descending direction. The input variables to obtain fitted 127 parameters ( , , , , , and ) are the time series of confirmed ( ( ) − ( ) − ( )), death 128 ( ( )), and recovered ( ( )) cases provided by from Johns Hopkins University Center for 129 Systems Science and Engineering 1 . The equations are solved using the classic 4th order Rungethe recent protests against police violence in cities across the United States 133 have gone ahead despite the current rising COVID-19 pandemic and potential subsequent 134 outbreaks, possibly with higher intensity. Large public gatherings, shouting, and marching 135 shoulder to shoulder may have already sown the seeds of the second outbreaks in regions under 136 initial control 19,20 and made it even more difficult to contain the epidemic in regions where the 137 curve is still increasing. The use of tear gas and pepper spray against the protesters may also 138 have produced violent coughing and runny noses, forcing protesters to remove their masks and 139 making the crowds even more susceptible to the virus. A certain number of patients with the 140 latent disease may have participated in the protests and spread the disease to healthy protesters, 141 police officers, and national guards who are not yet immune to the virus 21 . If the close contacts 142 of the infectious are not fully tracked, they may spread the virus to other groups of people, 143 increasing the risk of a larger size of outbreaks. Here, we simulated the impact of large-scale 144 protests on the potential second outbreaks in several cities of the United States 22 (Figure 2 and 145 Table 1). The model generally predicted a second wave of COVID-19 in the second half of 146 2020. We estimated the increase in the population of potentially infected people (δEt) for each 147 city based on the ratio of the number of infected persons (Qt) to the total population of the city 148 .

FIGREF4.text: of protesters (δSt, regarded as an increase in the population of susceptible) were 151 used as the force input for the model calculations to simulate the impact of protests on the 152 outbreaks. When the protests begin, we force group E and group S to increase δEt and δSt, The impact of protests on the possible second outbreak in Minneapolis. The blue 156 dots denote the reported daily incidence of COVID-19 cases. The blue line represents the 157 simulation and projections without protests, while the dashed red line denotes the simulation 158 and projections with protests. Four scenarios with protests and four scenarios without protests 159 are simulated. (a)~ (b), (c)~(d), (e)~(f), (g)~(h) are the simulation for Scenario 1, 2, 3). After the COVID-19 restrictions were lifted, an upward trend of daily new 166 cases has been observed. The protests would significantly amplify the intensity of the second 167 outbreak but may not be able to advance it. In scenarios 1, the second outbreak of Minneapolis 168 will peak in mid-August 2020. The comparison between scenarios indicates that the effect of 169 intervention measures outweighs the seasonal forcing. For the rest of the 12 cities, the model 170 also predicted enhanced second outbreaks when the impact of protests is considered(Table 1).171    Due to space constraints, the details of the projection results are not presented in the manuscript172    and can be accessed at http://covid-19.lzu.edu.

FIGREF6.text: restrictions, along with the enhancement in the ability of virus transmission in the 191 cold seasons due to temperature change may cause the recurrence of an outbreak that was 192 initially under control. If the same intervention measures are implemented during the second 193 outbreak, the second outbreak would be brought under control again by the end of 2020

FIGREF7.text: Projections of the second outbreak in India in different scenarios. Scenarios 1 199 and 2 are simulated with seasonal forcing, while scenarios 3 and 4 are simulated without 200 seasonal forcing. Scenarios 1 and 3 are the projections where restrictions are fully lifted, while 201 scenarios 2 and 4 are the projections where restrictions are partially lifted. 202 Mass gathering events during the epidemic should be restricted or even banned since they 203 have the potential to enhance the second outbreak and pose further radical public-health 204 challenges for health authorities and governments 23,24 . Lifting the restrictions too early may 205 also have the potential to trigger subsequent outbreaks and further increase the pressure on the 206 medical system. Fig 4 shows the projections of India in the four scenarios. With seasonal 207forcing, it is predicted that the first peak of the epidemic will occur in September while the 208 second peak with higher intensity, caused environmental changes, will arrive in January 2021.209    Without seasonal forcing, there would be only one peak in September 2020. We also projected 210 the epidemic curve for other countries including Russia, Brazil, Chile, etc. that are still in the 211 rapid growing period. We classified them as 'non-protesting countries', not because there are 212 no protests. Indeed, there might have been many protests and mass gatherings in India, Brazil,213    and other regions that may impact the outbreak on varying degrees, but the information on the 214 timing and size of these protests are currently not available. Therefore, the role of these protests 215 on the timing and size of the outbreaks can not be isolated and may not be incorporated as

FIGREF8.text: more suitable for the spread of disease 25 , an enhanced second outbreak is 222 expected. Therefore, when considering the timing of lifting the restrictions to restore the 223 economy, it is necessary to analyze epidemic situations as well as climate factors. For example, 224 during cold seasons when the transmission rate is higher, reopening would easily light up the 225 second outbreaks, since conducive environmental factors and related human social behaviors 226 (more frequent indoor gatherings) would, directly and indirectly, increase the transmission 227 ability of the virus, leaving more people vulnerable to infection. Therefore, the peak of the 228 second wave of the outbreak is most likely to synchronize with the fall of environmental 229 temperature, displaying strong seasonality. During winter months, the temperate regions of the 230 Northern and Southern Hemispheres experience highly synchronized annual influenza 231 epidemics 26 . Additionally, when restrictions are lifted, personal protection (wearing face masks, 232 keeping appropriate interpersonal distance, sterilization, etc) 27 . is still required or even 233 mandatory in indoor places so as to minimize the infection rate by cutting off the infection 234 routine.

FIGREF9.text: is inevitable as confirmed cases of COVID-19 increase. Our results show 241 that the timing and intensity of the second outbreaks are seasonally modulated and depend 242 largely on local reopening policies. Higher seasonal variations in COVID-19 transmission may 243 lead to a greater incidence of recurrent wintertime outbreaks 29 . The current mass protests in the 244 United States and other regions of the world could lead to amplified second outbreaks, 245 overlapping the wintertime outbreaks and threatening more lives. This is because the extremely 246 crowded environments facilitate the spread of the virus, leading to high rates of the second 247 attack, as seen in both the 1918 pandemic and the 1957 Asian influenza pandemic 30-32 . 248 If the transmission capacity of the second outbreak increases, it could place a catastrophic 249 burden on the health system and create even more serious social and economic crises. However, 250 if the chain of transmission is cut during the first outbreak, there will be no further outbreak 251 similar to the first wave. The necessary drug therapies and vaccines currently require long-term 252 development and testing, so nonpharmaceutical interventions are the only direct means 253 available to suppress the spread of the disease 33 . In the face of a powerful pandemic, everyone 254 must help to fight the virus. We must collectively follow the distancing limits recommended 255 by global public-health organizations to effectively reduce the potential cost in the lives of the 256 second wave of infection. Our findings should encourage close monitoring and early warning 257 of the development of a global pandemic, as well as safeguards for our global prediction system 258 to best contain the second wave 34 . These results provide a powerful scientific basis for 259 governments to adjust their policies and control measures in real-time, to achieve the most 260 effective allocation of medical resources before the second outbreak and to reduce
